DOCNAME: CASE OF VLADIMIROVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property
JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE . Her husband , Mr PERSON , born in DATE , and her mother , PERSON , born in DATE , are the second and third applicants . All applicants are NORP nationals and live in GPE .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicants purchased from the ORG a CARDINAL - room apartment of QUANTITY in the centre of GPE . Until then , the applicants’ family and CARDINAL other families had been sharing the apartment as tenants . The apartment had become ORG property by virtue of the nationalisations carried out by the communist regime in GPE in DATE and the following DATE . The apartment was on the third floor of a QUANTITY building constructed in DATE .
CARDINAL . After the adoption of LAW in DATE , the former pre - nationalisation owners brought proceedings under section CARDINAL of that law against the applicants .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE ORG found that the DATE transaction was null and void on several grounds , including abuse of office , since at the relevant time the second applicant ’s father had been an employee of the municipal real estate service . The applicants appealed .

CARDINAL . By judgment of DATE ORG upheld the lower court ’s judgment while it modified its reasoning . The court found that the allegation about abuse had remained unproven , the very fact that a relative of the applicants had worked in the municipal real estate service being insufficient .

CARDINAL . The court found , however , that a relevant document concerning the DATE transaction had been signed by the deputy to the official in whom the relevant power had been vested . The court considered that as a result the applicants’ title was null and void . The applicants were ordered to vacate the apartment .
CARDINAL . The judgment of ORG was recorded in the court ’s register on DATE . From that moment it became possible for the parties to learn about that judgment , if they visited the ORG registry .

CARDINAL . The applicants , who had been waiting for ORG judgment since DATE , the date of the last hearing , checked the register on an unspecified date between CARDINAL DATE and DATE . On DATE they submitted a petition for review ( cassation ) against ORG judgment .

CARDINAL . By decisions of CARDINAL DATE , DATE and DATE ORG decided that the cassation appeal had been submitted outside the relevant DATE time limit , which had expired on DATE and refused to renew that time limit . ORG agreed with the applicants that ORG had delivered its judgment DATE after the last hearing in the case and that the applicants had never been informed that the judgment had been ready and recorded . It found , however , that according to the relevant law the twomonth period for the submission of a petition for review ( cassation ) ran from the date on which the impugned judgment had been made available in the court ’s register .

CARDINAL . On unspecified dates DATE , it became possible for the applicants to obtain compensation from the ORG , in the form of bonds which could be used in privatisation tenders or sold to brokers . The applicants did not avail themselves of this opportunity .
CARDINAL . The applicants were evicted in DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicants were granted the tenancy of a CARDINAL - room municipal apartment , which they rented at low regulated price . In order to obtain this tenancy , the applicants were required to declare their financial situation .

CARDINAL . In DATE the municipality sold that apartment to the applicants for a regulated price below market value – CARDINAL NORP levs ( ORG ) , the equivalent of QUANTITY . The applicants paid , in addition , the equivalent of QUANTITY in fees .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicants issued proceedings for damages against the ORG under ORG , arguing that the ORG administration had been responsible for the omission that had led to the nullification of their title . In accordance with their practice in similar cases , the courts rejected those claims . The final judgment was delivered by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . The relevant background facts and domestic law and practice have been summarised in the ORG ’s judgment in the case of ORG and Others v. GPE , nos . CARDINAL , ORG , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , GPE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG , and CARDINAL , DATE .
